content.webTitle: Virgin Atlantic showed lack of concern when cancer forced flight change

fields.headline: Virgin Atlantic showed lack of concern when cancer forced flight change
fields.bodyText: I booked flights to Delhi for myself and a friend on Virgin Atlantic last September. In November, I was diagnosed with breast cancer and in December my surgeon said I should cancel the holiday as I could be having treatment during that period. Virgin said I could change the flights and that the fee for making a change could be waived if I was having treatment on the day of the flight. The next time I phoned, a different person told me that, unless I was actually going to be in hospital overnight on the day of travel, the fee could not be waived. Later I was told that I could not change the flights as the new dates are more than a year from the booking date. At no time previously had I been told this. If I cancel they will not refund the cost of the flight. AN, London Virgin says its terms and conditions differentiate between in-patients and out-patients but this is particularly restrictive now that hospitals avoid keeping patients in overnight as much as possible, and obviously you still can't fly while you are having out-patient treatment. However, it has given greater sympathy to your circumstances and agreed to refund the £100 it charged to amend your ticket and £300 for the difference in cost of the air fares which is high because you will be travelling at Easter, a more expensive time of year.
